div.p: I came here back in 2003 as an asylum seeker and I started in September 2003 at Central Technology College where I could not
speak a word of English, I didn’t know anything that was going on around me so at the time it was really difficult because you know you’ve got to
make friends, at that time you know you’ve got to fit in with other people as well you can’t just, you’ve got to learn the language
you’ve got to know your subjects, I was way behind what my fellow pupils you know were but I kept up with them you know and there were
some times when I was ahead of them because I worked really hard and I really dedicated myself to the language, I always wanted to learn English
it was really on my mind that I had to. It felt different but I felt happy that I was in that school because I had a good reception from the teachers,
from the students you know but the time goes by and you kind of feel you’re lonely, you know, even though I had great friends and all that
but it’s different but I kind of put that idea behind me so I said to myself this is my life now. Everyone from school, the teachers
really helped me I mean when I started I had a teacher she was supporting kids that didn’t have English as their first language
who were Asian kids and she helped me a lot I was with her for a few months and she really looked after me once I was settled in
and made sure that I was doing OK, making sure that I was getting what I needed and every teacher, you know, they were good to me
including everyone really because they were really supportive and they saw something in me that you know so they made me believe
more in myself; I did really good at school I got 8 A-Cs which I never thought I would get
